questions.statement: Length is a fundamental quantity.
questions.explanation: Length is one of the seven fundamental quantities in the SI system.

questions.statement: The SI unit of mass is gram.
questions.explanation: The SI unit of mass is kilogram (kg), not gram.

questions.statement: Vernier callipers can measure internal as well as external dimensions.
questions.explanation: Vernier callipers have both external jaws and internal jaws for these measurements.

questions.statement: Velocity is a scalar quantity.
questions.explanation: Velocity is a vector quantity as it has both magnitude and direction.

questions.statement: The least count of a screw gauge is smaller than that of vernier callipers.
questions.explanation: Screw gauge least count is 0.01 mm, while vernier callipers is 0.1 mm.

questions.statement: 1 light year is a unit of time.
questions.explanation: Light year is a unit of distance, equal to the distance traveled by light in one year.

questions.statement: Force is a derived quantity.
questions.explanation: Force = mass × acceleration, derived from fundamental quantities mass, length, and time.

questions.statement: The pitch of a screw gauge is 0.01 mm.
questions.explanation: The pitch of a standard screw gauge is 1 mm. The least count is 0.01 mm.

questions.statement: Angle is a dimensionless quantity.
questions.explanation: Angle = arc/radius = length/length, making it dimensionless.

questions.statement: The prefix 'kilo' represents 10^6.
questions.explanation: Kilo represents 10^3 (thousand). Mega represents 10^6.

questions.statement: There are 10 divisions on the vernier scale of a standard vernier callipers.
questions.explanation: A standard vernier callipers has 10 divisions on the vernier scale.

questions.statement: Newton is a fundamental unit.
questions.explanation: Newton is a derived unit of force (kg·m/s²).

questions.statement: Dimensional analysis can determine the numerical constants in equations.
questions.explanation: Dimensional analysis cannot determine dimensionless numerical constants.

questions.statement: 1 angstrom is larger than 1 nanometre.
questions.explanation: 1 Å = 10^-10 m, while 1 nm = 10^-9 m. So nanometre is larger.

questions.statement: The ratchet in a screw gauge helps in applying uniform pressure.
questions.explanation: The ratchet ensures consistent pressure is applied during measurement.

questions.statement: Work and torque have different dimensions.
questions.explanation: Both have the same dimensions [M L^2 T^-2], though they represent different concepts.

questions.statement: Zero error always gives a reading less than the true value.
questions.explanation: Positive zero error gives higher readings; negative gives lower readings.

questions.statement: Kelvin is the SI unit of temperature.
questions.explanation: Kelvin (K) is the SI fundamental unit of thermodynamic temperature.

questions.statement: A physical quantity can be completely described by its magnitude alone if it is a vector.
questions.explanation: Vectors need both magnitude and direction; scalars need only magnitude.

questions.statement: The vernier scale slides along the main scale.
questions.explanation: The vernier scale (with movable jaw) slides along the fixed main scale.

questions.statement: 1 fermi is equal to 10^-15 metres.
questions.explanation: 1 fermi (femtometre) = 10^-15 m, used for nuclear dimensions.

questions.statement: Speed and velocity have the same dimensions.
questions.explanation: Both have dimensions [L T^-1], though velocity is a vector.

questions.statement: The CGS unit of force is Newton.
questions.explanation: The CGS unit of force is dyne. Newton is the SI unit.

questions.statement: Precision and accuracy mean the same thing in measurement.
questions.explanation: Accuracy is closeness to true value; precision is consistency of readings.

questions.statement: Electric current is a fundamental quantity in SI system.
questions.explanation: Electric current (ampere) is one of the seven SI fundamental quantities.

questions.statement: The circular scale of a screw gauge usually has 50 divisions.
questions.explanation: A standard screw gauge has 100 divisions on its circular scale.

questions.statement: Joule and Newton-metre have the same dimensions.
questions.explanation: Both are units of energy/work with dimensions [M L^2 T^-2].

questions.statement: A metre scale can measure lengths up to 0.1 mm accurately.
questions.explanation: A metre scale typically has least count of 1 mm, not 0.1 mm.

questions.statement: The dimension formula [M L^2 T^-3] represents power.
questions.explanation: Power = Work/Time = [M L^2 T^-2]/[T] = [M L^2 T^-3].

questions.statement: Specific gravity has a unit.
questions.explanation: Specific gravity is the ratio of densities, so it is unitless and dimensionless.
